title: 106_s884
content: Establishment of National Military Museum Foundation under new chapter 1520 in title 36, United States Code. The National Military Museum Foundation is established as a nonprofit corporation with purposes including preserving military artifacts, promoting innovative solutions for preservation, and facilitating research and educational activities. The National Military Museum Foundation aims to facilitate research, promote partnerships for artifact preservation, display artifacts for public education, develop interpretive materials, provide financial support for educational programs, and enhance public understanding of the military's role in US history. The National Military Museum Foundation recognizes and honors individuals who have served in the Armed Forces. Membership eligibility and rights are determined by the Foundation's constitution and bylaws. The Foundation's Board of Directors, appointed by the Secretary of Defense, includes individuals with expertise in historic preservation, military history, and museum administration. The Board of Directors of the National Military Museum Foundation is appointed by the Secretary of Defense and includes individuals with expertise in historic preservation, military history, and museum administration. The Board members serve for a term of 4 years and the chairperson is designated by the Secretary for a 2-year term. If a member misses three consecutive meetings, they may be removed from the Board. The Board may remove a member for missing three consecutive meetings. Vacancies on the Board must be filled within 60 days. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, which must occur at least once a year. The initial Board members must establish the Foundation as a nonprofit corporation by adopting a constitution and bylaws. The Foundation may appoint an executive director and other officers, who will be compensated by the Board. The Foundation can also hire employees and accept volunteers with Board approval. Federal employees cannot work for the Foundation. The Foundation has the power to accept gifts, enter contracts, and carry out activities as deemed appropriate by the executive director. It must maintain its tax-exempt status under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Foundation must maintain its tax-exempt status under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and submit annual reports to the Secretary of Defense on its activities. The National Military Museum Foundation, established by chapter 1520 of title 36, United States Code, may receive a grant of $250,000 for fiscal year 2000 to support its activities. The Secretary of Defense can provide personnel, facilities, and administrative services to the Foundation from 2000 to 2002 without reimbursement.
